item.name: Acquire
item.comment: Good pure investment/stock game, with a touch of randomness from the tiles. Works better at 4 than at 6.

item.name: Air, Land, and Sea: Critters at War
Architects of the West Kingdom
item.comment: Oct 2021: After more plays, the synergy between the apprentices and your strategies becomes more interesting, especially with the variable player powers. Rating is thus improved a bit. Sept 2021: Architects is a medium-weight worker placement game. The most innovative aspect of the game is the capture mechanics and the virtuous track, which is fun initially, but getting stale and 'samey' after repeated plays. The different combos between the apprentices and the buildings are interesting, but they are not easy to pull off, especially at high player counts due to the luck of the draw. Interaction is limited to capturing, but it can become a distraction if not carefully planned. For solo, the AI is easy to run but it is quite random and not really challenging. The components are nice, except for the small box. Overall, it is an average game, suitable for family but not for gamers who want deep strategy.

item.name: Architects of the West Kingdom: Age of Artisans
item.comment: Dec 2021: A fine expansion that can be added seamlessly into the base game, though I suggest everyone should play the base game at least once before trying this. The extra mechanisms (artisan + crafting cards) really provide an additional layer of strategy without compromising the playing time or complexity. Overall, this is an essential expansion and I will never play Architect without it.

item.name: Arydia: The Paths We Dare Tread
Brass: Birmingham
item.comment: [Mar 2022] A tight economic game with a brilliant card system where each card is an action. The board seems static at first but the more you play, the more nuances you can see how the market set-up immensely affects the interaction of the industries. The way all the resources (coal, iron, beer) interlink with each other and how your money should be managed to efficiently capitalize on all that is extremely interesting. The best part of this game IMO is the "cooperative competitiveness" feature (to quote Mr Martin Fowler from Heavy Cardboard) when you flip your opponent's tiles or vice versa. It leads to a continuous stream of delicious and tense decision every turn. The only drawbacks are the potential huge AP-ness and the long playtime from it. Overall, an outstanding economic game from Mr Wallace. Thank you!

item.name: Cat in the Box: Deluxe Edition
The Crew: The Quest for Planet Nine
Darwin's Journey
item.comment: Backed on Kickstater Collector's Edition

item.name: Dead Reckoning
item.comment: [Apr 2023]: Great game with a variety of strategies which seem balance so far. You can be a terrified pirate or a hardworking merchant and still have an equal shot at winning. The card upgrade system is really unique and fun to explore. The combat system is creative and not to punishing. The only downside is the long game length (about 4 hours for 4 players) so it will be hard to get this play again at high player count. 2-3 players seem optimal for now. Will try to explore the Saga soon.

item.name: Decrypto
item.comment: Oct 2021: A fun team-based party game that is both deep and fun for large group, with almost infinite replayability

item.name: Deep Sea Adventure
item.comment: [Mar 2022]: Fun, fast, and relaxing push-your-luck game as long as you don't take winning too seriously. A super portable box is a great plus as a travel game.

item.name: Dune: Imperium â€“ Rise of Ix
Gaia Project
item.comment: [Mar 2022]: 3 plays physical, 9 plays on BGA The more you play, the deeper you can see and feel the strategy, especially from the unique factions. The ways the factions interact with each other and with each different initial board set-up are brilliant. There is no luck in this game: if you plan your strategy well you will get what you want. However, beware of its tactical aspect because it can make or break your game: the timing of the special actions, the jostling of positions on the map, the capitalizing on the round bonuses/booster tiles, and the charging of your power. The physical components are of high-quality though a third-party insert is recommended for easier set up and tear down. The only downside could be from the long playing time initially and the large learning curve but the efforts will eventually paid off. Overall, this is an excellent game for eurogame lovers.

item.name: Ginkgopolis
item.comment: [Nov 2021]: The below comment is still true but one caveat at full player count at 5 is that it can become quite a bit chaotic to plan properly, due to the luck of the cards and tiles. Overall, it is still a good game though the rating drops a bit (8.5 -> 8.0) [May 2021]: Great medium game with a great mix of mechanisms: card drafting, engine building, resource management, and area control. The interaction is competitively interesting in building the city. The rules are a bit confusing at first but get internalized easily after a few rounds. The only downside is the lack of theme and the fiddling setting up of the draw pile between rounds. Overall, it is a fun next-step game and highly recommended for any gaming groups.

item.name: Hansa Teutonica: Big Box
item.comment:
[Dec 2021]: The Eastern map really made the game more interesting. The additional mechanics (maritime routes, green cities) and some map modifications (2 upgrades in one city) magically made the game feel less tight, less scripted, and created more paths to victory. Overall, the map retained the trademark elegance of Hansa without compromising the complexity or interaction.
[Nov 2021]: This is a great network-building area-control old-school Euro game. The interaction is through the roof, where you often play against the players rather than the game. The rules are simple, the map is straightforward, but every decision you make is interesting and can be game changing. It is a more tactical (75%) than a strategic game (25%). Because of this, despite some claims about scripted openings, the game state will evolve very fast into different directions after a few turns, so you don't need to worry too much about this. One caveat that I may have though is that not all the expansion content in the big box is important . I think the base game is good enough, but if you want to spice up the game, the Mission cards and the Eastern map should be sufficient without compromising its elegance. Overall, this is truly a classic and a gem for any Euro gamer out there that love interaction.

item.name: Hegemony: Lead Your Class to Victory
Infinity Gauntlet: A Love Letter Game
Lost Ruins of Arnak
item.comment: Played on BGA (40+ times) A fun resource management game. Upon more playthroughs, the game is more balanced than expected. Though the main aim is still racing to the top of the research track, finding the ways to do that as efficient as possible is the charm of the game. However, the limited player interaction and the samey feel of repeated play are the minus points for me. Overall, it is still a chill mid-weight euro game that all can enjoy on the weekend or after a tiring working day.

item.name: Maracaibo
item.comment: Aug 2021: Maracaibo is a multiplayer solitaire and point salad game with a lot of mechanisms mixed together, making it very fiddly and AP prone. Nonetheless, specialization in certain aspects of the game is rewarding. The solo AI is easy to run and the campaign is ok. However, the very big minus is the long set up and tear down time (all the quest/combat tiles, combat cubes, ship upgrade tokens, card shuffling, legacy tiles, etc.), making it hard to get to the table. Overall, a good but not excellent game.

item.name: Modern Art
item.comment: Oct 2021: An epitome of auction game that is both streamlined and deep enough for repeated plays. It is more fun with beginners/intermediates than experienced/serious players because there will be a better mix of gut instincts and calculations during bidding. Overall, it truly stands the test of time as a classic Knizia.

item.name: On Mars
item.comment: [Mar 2022] A great thematic game about exploring and colonizing Mars. Each turn you are facing with a number of delicious and agonizing choices of what to do: Staying or leaving the planet? Get your own tech or use your friend's? Construct a basic building for short-run attractive bonuses or upgrade to an advanced building for long-term strategy? Hire a scientist for more bonus actions or Get a contract for huge points? And so many more. The most exciting aspect is how all these questions are interlinked to each other, and if you plan well enough, you can chain a few of these actions in 1 turn, how sweet is that? A superb production value, from the art to the double-layered boards to the detailed meeples, is a great plus. However, one small drawback is the long playing time and a long teach for your first few plays (4-5 hours for 3-4 players) but rest assured that the efforts will be paid off. Overall, it is an excellent sandbox game from Mr Vital Lacerda. Thank you!

item.name: Root: The Exiles and Partisans Deck
item.comment: Essential expansion

item.name: The Search for Planet X
item.comment: Sep 2021 [Solo play only] This is the best deduction game for solo I have played until now. The app runs smoothly and the bot is very well-designed. It does a great job in constantly giving you the pressure to find planet X and publish (or perish). The set up is very easy, the components are great, and the amount of variability is top notch. In terms of gameplay, the deduction puzzle goes beyond simple elimination (like some other deduction games) and requires you to really put all the clues together. The best part of the game is that you can control what clues you want to get so luck is minimized. Overall, this is an excellent deduction game that everyone should try (at least for the solo aspect).

item.name: Smartphone Inc.
item.comment: Feb 2021: A medium-weight economic board game with elegant design and high accessibility for new players. Variability comes mostly from the technology and directives. The gameplay is much more interactive and intense at full player count (5 for the large board, 3 for the small board) due to the tight competition over the markets. The scenarios are also great add-ons for the gameplay. Overall, it is an enjoyable playing experience and is recommended for those groups who want to step up from the normal gateway games.

item.name: Spirit Island
item.comment: One of the best co-op games

item.name: Stockpile: Epic Edition
item.comment: Feb 2021: A fun stock market game that is very streamlined, thematic, and accessible to new players. Though interaction is limited, players need to constantly pay attention to others to pick up any hints of insider information, which is the most exciting part of the game. Variability comes from many modules that are included in the KS edition (bonds, commodity, investment strategies, etc.) but inclusion of these modules depends greatly on each play group. The starting characters can create a very imbalance problem so playing with these may be optional. Overall, this can be a great gateway games for the stockmarket theme.

item.name: Sushi Go Party!
item.comment: Good family game

item.name: Terraforming Mars
item.comment: Mar 2021: a game with relatively simple rule overhead but with a variety of strategies. Players need to balance between many mechanics (resource management, engine-building, hand management, area control, etc) to achieve the most desirable outcomes: collectively terraforming mars and individually gaining the highest points. Though the game is on a longer side (3-4 hours for our group with 3-4 players), the common feedback received was that it did not "feel long". One downside of this game is that there is very limited interaction and the components are very disappointing. Nonetheless, due to the high replayability and deep strategy involved, it really earns its place in the top ranking of the BGG list.

item.name: Terraforming Mars: Prelude
item.comment: Essential expansion

item.name: Tiny Towns
item.comment: May 2021: A fun city building game for up to 6 players. The rules are simple but the decision space is huge. The different building types create great variability and replayability, which is a huge plus for me. The optimal player count IMO is 4-5 because the more number of players, the less control you have on your board. Interaction is top-notch and hilarious because bad words are guaranteed to be heard at some points in the game. Overall, it is a fun gateway game that is suitable and recommended to any gaming group.

item.name: Unmatched: Battle of Legends, Volume One
